A type of malware that can replicate itself and spread from one computer to another. Needs host file (usually)
A type of malware that can spread without the need for a host file.
A type of malware that disguises itself as legitimate software in order to trick users into installing it.
A type of malware that records every keystroke that a user makes.
A type of malware that collects information about a user's activities, such as their browsing history and passwords.
A type of malware that allows an attacker to gain unauthorized access to a computer system.
A type of malware that encrypts a user's files and demands a ransom payment in order to decrypt them.
Program that secretly performs crypto mining in the background
A type of malware that can take control of a computer and make it perform tasks without the user's knowledge or consent.

A network of infected computers that are controlled by a bot. Botnets can be used to carry out a variety of malicious activities, such as sending spam, launching denial-of-service attacks, and stealing data.
A type of malware that is designed to steal data from a computer. Rookits are often disguised as legitimate software, such as games or productivity tools.
A type of malware that is activated at a predetermined time or event. Time bombs are often used to destroy data or disrupt computer operations.
A type of malware that is activated when a specific condition is met. Logic bombs are often used to steal data or disrupt computer operations.
Targeted phishing
Spear phishing when target is senior leadership
VOIP phishing
SMS phishing
Spam instant messaging
Spam over Bluetooth
Adding info to message to make it look legit (e.g., "Re:" in subject line)
An attacker presents a fabrication of a legitimate reason they would need access to a system or resource even though they’ve not been granted access
Using information (often obtained through social engineering attacks) to present oneself as another. Loans and even mortgages are often fraudulently obtained through this means
Sending invoices purporting to be from legitimate companies in hopes that they will be paid without further investigation
Chain letters, promises of financial gain, and other deceptive messages
User traffic redirected by attacker to look-alike sites that are actually malicious
Websites that look like a trusted site, but are actually malicious
Brute force attack using combinations of words from a document
Table of hashes of common passwords
Manipulating or extracting data, bypassing security measures, unauthorized actions
Injecting code into a running process, modifying program behavior
Manipulating queries, bypassing authentication mechanisms, unauthorized access
Unexpected behavior, security vulnerabilities, code execution, data tampering
Trying to find some input that generates the same hash, but actual inputs might be different
Same as collision attack
Attacker requests server to use older services/protocols to that may have vulnerabilities.
Exploiting vulnerabilities to inject and execute malicious scripts
Forging unauthorized actions by exploiting user's trust, user clicks on bad link that send data back to attacker
Exploiting variations in response times to gather information
Overwriting adjacent memory locations or exceeding integer limits
Unintentional retention of allocated memory, potentially leading to resource exhaustion or information exposure
Malisous script in website gets user’s cookies to attacker
Attacker sends link with malicious script in it, which reflects cookies off user to attacker
Passwords or session that have be captured and then used later (without change)
Sending unsolicited messages over Bluetooth (spamming)
Unauthorized access to a Bluetooth device
Exploiting a serial connection to gain full control of transmitted data
Copying identifing features of a device (IP, MAC, etc) to impersonate victum
Automatically adjusting resource utilization based on performance needs
The ability to add/remove hardware/software resources for different usage levels
